item.content:encoded:
Zondervan’s New Studies in Dogmatics series will be one to watch. I’m intrigued by several features in the announcement.

The series’s title and genre derives from G. C. Berkouwer’s mid-twentieth century, single-author, eighteen-volume Dutch neo-Calvinist series, Dogmatische studiën (Studies in Dogmatics). It will be interesting to see how a multi-author (none of whom are Dutch or share the same denominational affiliation, most of whom are Americans, all of whom are brilliant), sixteen-volume series compares in terms of thematic, stylistic, and material unity.

And it will be also interesting to see what questions are being brought to the forefront in Reformed evangelical theology a half century after Berkouwer’s massive project. 

I am heartened that the editors have chosen to include the doctrine of God (divine names and Trinity) among the loci covered in the new series; for Berkouwer’s omission of this fundamental locus is perplexing indeed.
